title-group.article-title: Effect of a treat-to-target intervention of cardiovascular risk factors on subclinical and clinical atherosclerosis in rheumatoid arthritis: a randomisedzed clinical trial

fn.label: Contributors
fn.p: DFvB-vdS, JvZ and MCC conceived and designed the study. BB, MAdV, DFvB-vdS, BK and NvdM performed the study. BB, EB and MCC performed the statistical analysis. BB and MCC drafted the manuscript. All authors contributed to interpretation and edited the draft report. BB and MCC had full access to the data and take responsibility for the integrity of the data and the accuracy of the data analysis.

file.file-caption: Caption: Flow diagram of participants through the trial Legend: Data from patients who withdrew early from the study were included in the intention-to-treat analysis and follow-up information with respect to cardiovascular events was obtained with permission. For those who were lost to follow-up, no information regarding cardiovascular outcomes could be obtained and these were excluded for the secondary outcome analysis.

Caption: Changes in selected risk factors during follow-up Legend: Shown are mean (standard error of the mean) of systolic blood pressure (Panel A), hemoglobin A1c (Panel B), low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (Panel C), and carotid Intima Media Thickness (Panel D) for the usual care () and treat-to-target intervention group () during five years of follow-up. The total number of patients in both groups was 320 (baseline), 251 (year 1), 236 (year 2), 238 (year 3), 221 (year 4) and 216 (year 5). Panel E shows the percentage of patients in each group who reached treatment goals for the treat-to-target intervention group at the end of the study. *p<0.05 for the comparison between usual care and the treat-to-target intervention group.
file.file_tag: After five years, there was no

file.file-caption: Caption:"Kaplan-Meier estimates of the composite of first occurrence of fatal and nonfatal cardiovascular events during five years of follow-up Legend: Shown is the cumulative incidence of the composite endpoint of first occurrence of fatal and nonfatal cardiovascular events, including death by cardiovascular cause, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, coronary artery bypass grafting, percutaneous coronary intervention, revascularisation of peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease, or amputation related to peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: : Patients with Rrheumatoid Aarthritis (RA) have an increased risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD). No long-term intervention trials on CVD risk factors have been published, and a debate on the efficacy of controlling traditional risk factors in RA is ongoing. We aimed to evaluate a treat-to-target approach versus usual care regarding traditional CVD risk factors in patients with RA.

: In this open-label, randomizedrandomised controlled trial, patients with RA patients aged < 70 years without prior CVD or diabetes mellitus were randomised 1:1 to either a treat-to-target approach or usual care of traditional CVD risk factors. The primary outcome was defined as change in carotid intima media thickness (cIMT) over five5 years, and the secondary outcome was a composite of first occurrence of fatal and non-fatal cardiovascular events.

: A total of 320 patients (mean age 52.4 years; 69.7 % female) with RA underwent randomisationzation and 219 patients (68.4%) completed 5 years of follow-up. The Mmean cIMT progression was significantly reduced in the treat-to-target group compared tocompared with usual care (0.023 [(95% confidence intervalCI 0.011 –to 0.036)] mm vs 0.045 ([95% confidence intervalCI 0.030 –to 0.059) ] mm; p = 0.028). Cardiovascular events occurred in 2 (1.3%) of the patients in the treat-to-target group vs 7 (4.7%) in those receiving usual care (p = 0.048 by log-rank test).
: This study provides evidence foron the benefit of a treat-to-target approach of traditional CVD risk factors for primary prevention in patients with well-treated patients with RA patients.

boxed-text.title: What does this study add?What is already known about this subject?

list-item.p: · Patients with rheumatoid arthritis have an increased risk for cardiovascular disease;, however, no studies on interventions studies aiming at traditional cardiovascular risk factors in these patients have been published so far.

· This randomisedzed- controlled trial in patients with rheumatoid arthritis suggests that a treat-to-target intervention of traditional cardiovascular risk factors leads to reduced subclinical and clinical atherosclerosis.

boxed-text.title: How might this impact on clinical practice or future developments?

p.named-content: These findings provide for the first- time evidence foron the efficacy of cardiovascular riskrisk management in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

body.p: Corresponding author:

p.data-style: font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 12.0pt; margin-left: 0cm; margin-right: 0cm; margin: 0cm; margin-bottom: .0001pt; line-height: 200%;

body.p: Manuel Castro Cabezas, Department of Internal Medicine, Center for Diabetes and Vascular Medicine, Franciscus Gasthuis & Vlietland, Rotterdam, the Netherlands

Rheumatoid Aarthritis (RA) has been associated with an increased risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD).1–4 The presence of RA has been linked to a 50% increase in risk for CVD compared tocompared with the general population.4 5 Since atherosclerosis is, in part, an inflammatory process,6 the ongoing inflammation in RA may play an important role in the development of atherosclerosis.7 8 Several studies have shown that effective treatment of disease activity with immunomodulatory drugs in RA is associated with a reduced cardiovascular risk.9–14

Besides inflammation, traditional CVD risk factors contribute to the increased cardiovascular risk in RA. There is a higher prevalence of hypercholesterolaemia, hypertension, smoking, and obesity,15 16 and these risk factors are underdiagnosed and undertreated in patients with RA.17 A recent study showed that 30% of the CVD events waswere attributed to RA characteristics and 49% to traditional CVD risk factors.18 The importance of these risk factors has been strengthened by guidelines recommending CVD risk estimation in patients with RA patients by modification of the traditional risk models.19 20 Due to these adaptations, more patients with RA patients will be identified and treated for their CVD risk. Limited data on the effect of primary prevention in patients with RA patients isare available. Several population-based studies showed a relation between use of statins and a reduced cardiovascular risk.21 22 To date, however, the effect of a multifactorial intervention of traditional CVD risk factors on clinical and subclinical atherosclerosis in RA has not been reported.

In the present study, we aimed to evaluate the effect of a predefined treat-to-target intervention of cardiovascular risk factors on structural vascular changes and cardiovascular outcomes compared tocompared with usual care.
body.title: Study design and population
body.p: As described previously,23 the Franciscus Rheumatoid Arthritis and Cardiovascular Intervention Study (FRANCIS)(FRANCIS) is an open-label, single-centre, randomizedrandomised clinical trial. The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Franciscus Gasthuis, Rotterdam, the Netherlands and the regional independent medical research ethics committee TWOR, Rotterdam. All participants gave written informed consent. The study was registered at the Netherlands trial register (trialregister.nl; NTR3873).

Patients aged ≤70 years with RA (defined according to the American College of Rheumatology 1987 criteria24) attending the Rrheumatology outpatient clinic at the Franciscus Gasthuis were consecutively invited to participate. Exclusion criteria were the presence of diabetes mellitus (either a documented diagnosis or a hemoglobinhaemoglobin A1c ([HbA1c]) >48 mmol/mol) or CVD. The latter was defined as a documented history of myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular disease, amputation due to peripheral artery disease, intermittent claudication, or a prior percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty, or coronary artery bypass graft. In addition, kidney disease, defined as an estimated glomerular filtration rate <40 mL/min/1.73 m2 , was an exclusion criterion.

Before randomisationzation, the CVD risk score was calculated according to the 2006 unadjusted Systematic Coronary Risk Evaluation (SCORE) risk assessment.25 Patients with a 10 -year CVD risk <10% were randomizedrandomised (1:1) to either treat-to-target intervention or usual care by means of opaque sealed envelopes. Patients with a 10 -year CVD risk ≥10% were included in a separate “‘high risk cohort”’.
body.title: Procedures
body.p: All patients visited the Ddiabetes and Vvascular centre outpatient clinic twice a year;, a standardizedstandardised set of non-fasting blood samples were obtained at these visits and anthropomorphic measurements (eg, blood pressure, weight, and height) were recorded. Blood samples at baseline were obtained after an overnight fast. Carotid ultrasound scans were carried out once a year using the ART-LAB (Esaote, Italy) by a trained and experienced sonographer as described earlier.26 Two different assessors measured the carotid intima mediamedia thickness (cIMT) of the same patients throughout the trial (intra-observer intraclass correlation coefficient ([ICC]) 0.95, smallest detectable change ([SDC]) 0.0025 mm; interobserver ICC 0.91, SDC 0.053 mm). An atherosclerotic plaque was defined as a lesion with a focal cIMT of 1.0 mm or more, with a localizedlocalised protrusion of the vessel wall into the lumen.

Treatment for RA for all participants was carried out by the patient’s’ own rheumatologist, aiming for RA disease remission, following state -of -the -art treatment as described in the most recent RA guidelines.27 28 No limitation was set on the type of treatment. RA disease activity was assessed by the Disease Activity Score (DAS28) with 28 joints evaluated and the erythrocyte sedimentation ratio (ESR) was scored at every visit. Remission was classified as either DAS-based or Boolean -based.29 Low disease activity was defined as DAS28 ≤3.3.

Concerning CVD risk management, patients with RA patients in the usual care group were only evaluated and their general physician received written advice based on the results of the visits;, however, initiation of treatment was based on their own judgement and CVD risk guidelines.

Patients with RA patients within the treat-to-target group were treated according to a pre-specified protocol. Anti-hypertensive treatment was initiated when hypertension was diagnosed. Hypertension was defined as a mean blood pressure of >140/90 mm Hg obtained from measurements over 15 min or, if necessary, from a 24 -hours ambulant blood pressure measurement. The Ffirst choice of treatment was perindopril 4 mg once daily, and when the treatment target was not met, the dosage was increased to 8 mg once daily. Other agents were added to reach the treatment target if necessary, first, with the addition of indapamide 2.5 mg once daily, followed by the addition of a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker.

Treatment with lipid -lowering drugs was initiated when either low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) was >3.0 mmol/L, apolipoprotein (apo) B >0.90 g/L, or triglycerides >2.20 mmol/L. Treatment was initiated with simvastatin 40 mg once daily, and if the targets were not met the dosage was increased to a maximum of maximal 80 mg once daily or ezetimibe 10 mg once daily was added. In the case of an isolated hypertriglyceridaemia (triglycerides >2.20 mmol/L), bezafibrate 400 mg once daily was initiated.

Dietary and lifestyle advices werewas given in case of low high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) (≤1.2 mmol/L for womenfemales and ≤1.0 mmol/L for malesmen) and/or a body mass index (BMI) >25 kg/m2. In the case of smoking, cessation was advised and a referral to the outpatient clinic for smoking cessation was offered.
In the case of HbA1c >48 mmol/mol, patients were treated initially with metformin, and when the response was insufficient additional drugs were added.
body.title: End points
body.p: The primary outcome was progression of cIMT between baseline and five5 years of follow-up. The secondary outcome was a composite endpoint of first occurrence of death by cardiovascular causes, non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, coronary artery bypass grafting, percutaneous coronary intervention, revascularisation of peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease, or amputation related to peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease between baseline and five5 years of follow-up. If a patient experienced more than one cardiovascular event, only the first was included in the analyses.
Endpoints were assessed by the study team by reviewing the medical file and information from the general practitioner. Assessment of endpoints was blinded and by means of consensus.
body.title: Statistical analysis
body.p: This study was primarily designed to show a reduced progression of the cIMT in the treat-to-target group compared tocompared with usual care. Assuming an average increase of 0.025±0.015 mm by usual care and 0.020±0.015 mm by the treat-to-target intervention, with a 1:1 randomisationzation ratio, a type 1 error of 0.05 (two-sided) and a statistical power of 0.80, a total of 2×143 patients should be included in the analysis.

To account for the high drop-out, all missing cIMT values after 5 years of follow-up were imputed with all available cIMT values (baseline, years 1–4) and treatment group as covariate. Assuming that unobserved cIMT values were missing at random, missing data waswere imputed with multiple imputation using the fully conditional specification (FCS)30 method for 7seven cycles.

As part of the imputation procedure, a generalizedgeneralised linear model (GLM) was used with progression of the cIMT as the dependent variable and treatment group, sex, and cIMT assessor as adjusting covariates. The mean difference in cIMT was calculated by the least square method. Calculations were performed of each imputation cycle and the mean of the pooled results areis presented.

To assess the robustness of the intervention effect on cIMT, a repeated measurements analysis (linear mixed -effect model) was used with cIMT as the dependent variable, time as repeated measure (covariance type: unstructured), and treatment group, sex, baseline cIMT, DAS28, methotrexate use, biological use,, and the interaction between treatment group and time as covariates.

For the analyses of the secondary outcomes, Kaplan-Meier time-to-event analysis werewas used, with log-rank tests for the comparison of treatment groups. All endpoints were analysed according to the intention-to-treat principle, with the exception of patients in whom no data regarding cardiovascular outcomes could be recorded. These patients were reported as lost to follow-up.

Differences between groups in were determined using the unpaired Student’s t-test, Mann--Whitney U test or χ2Chi-square test, where appropriate. Differences between baseline and follow-up were tested with either a paired t-test for continuous variables with normal distribution, Wilcoxon Ssigned- Rrank test for continuescontinuous variables with skewed distributions, or the McNemar test for dichotomous variables.

A p- value <0.05 (two-sided) was considered a statistically significant difference. All statistical analyses were performed using PASW Statistics version V.23.0 (IBM SPSS Statistics, New York, USAnited States).

Between February 2011 and December 2012, 335 patients were assessed for eligibility and 320 patients were randomly assigned to the treat-to-target intervention (n=162) or usual care (n=158) (Figure 1figure 1). The characteristics of the the patients were similar at baseline except for female sex (Table 1table 1). Of the randomizedrandomised patients, 219 patients (68.4%) completed the 5 years of follow-up, with 116 patients in the treat-to-target group vs 103 in the usual care group. There were no differences in baseline characteristics in those who did and did not complete follow-up (data not shown).

caption.title: Flow diagram of participants through the triall. Data from patients who withdrew early from the study were included in the intention-to-treat analysis and follow-up information with respect to cardiovascular events was obtained with permission. For those who were lost to follow-up, no information regarding cardiovascular outcomes could be obtained and these were excluded for the secondary outcome analysis. who withdrew early from the study were included in the intention-to-treat analysis, and follow-up information with respect to cardiovascular events was obtained with permission. fFor those who were lost to follow-up, no information regarding cardiovascular outcomes could be obtained and these were excluded forin the secondary outcome analysis.

named-content.xlink:title: Gowtham Ram (TYPESETTER)

def-list.def-item:
DAS28,
Disease Activity Score with 28 joints counted and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate;

body.p: After five5 years, there was no difference in mean systolic blood pressure between those allocated to treat-to-target versus usual care (124.6 [(15.8]) mm Hg vs 124.7 ([14.6]) mm Hg; p=0.97) (Figure 2Afigure 2A). Furthermore, there was no difference in the percentage of participants who reached treat-to-target treatment targets for blood pressure (72.4% for usual care vs 75.9% for treat-to-target; p=0.56) (Figure 2Efigure 2E).

caption.title: Changes in selected risk factors during follow-upp. Shown are mean ( sShown are mean (standard errorSEM of the mean) of systolic blood pressure (Panel A), of the mean) of systolic blood pressure (Apanel a), hemoglobinhaemoglobin A1c (Panel B), low-density lipoprotein ( A1c (Bpanel B), low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (Panel C), and ) cholesterol (Cpanel C), and carotid Iintima Mmedia Tthickness (Panel D) for the usual care (●) and treat-to-target intervention group (◼) during (Dpanel D) for the usual care (●) and treat-to-target Iintervention Ggroup (◼) during five5 years of follow-up. The total number of patients in both groups was 320 (baseline), 251 (year 1), 236 (year 2), 238 (year 3), 221 (year 4) and 216 (year 5). Panel E shows the percentage of in both groups was 320 (baseline), 251 (year 1), 236 (year 2), 238 (year 3), 221 (year 4) and 216 (year 5). panel (E) Tshows the percentage of patients in each group who reached treatment goals for the treat-to-target intervention group at the end of the study. in each group who reached treatment goals for the treat-to-target Iintervention group at the end of the study. *Pp<0.05 for the comparison between usual care and the treat-to-target intervention group. for the comparison between usual care and the treat-to-target Iintervention Ggroup.

body.p: There was no difference in mean HbA1c between groups after five5 years (37.0 ([4.6]) mmol/mol) vs 37.6 [(5.5]) mmol/mol); p=0.39) (Figure 2Bfigure 2B). In both groups, over 98% of participants had values below the HbA1c- target for the treat-to-target group (p=0.80).

A significant and persistent lower LDL-C within one1 year in the treat-to-target group versus usual care was found. The mean LDL-C was 2.5 (0.8) mmol/L for treat-to-target vs 3.1 (0.9) mmol/L for usual care after five5 years (p<0.0001) (Figure 2Cfigure 2C). Significantly more patients in the treat-to-target group had LDL-C values below the treat-to-target group target (75.6% vs 48.6% for usual care; p<0.0001).

During five5 years of follow-up, the RA was well controlled in both groups, reflected by comparable low values of both DAS28 and ESR between groups ((onlineonline supplementary figure s1) ). More patients in the treat-to-target group were on statin treatment (48.3% vs 18.4%; p<0.0001). There were no significant differences in the use of other medications (see Table 2table 2).

caption.title: Medication use at baseline and after five5 years of follow-up.

Significantly different from the corresponding value in the usual care group (p<0.05).

body.p: At baseline, there was no difference in mean cIMT between those allocated to treat-to-target and usual care (0.570 [(0.108]) mm versus 0.569 ([0.113]) mm; p=0.91). Subjects allocated to treat-to-target showed a reduced mean progression of cIMT after five5 years of follow-up compared tocompared with the usual care (0.023 ([95% CI 0.011 to 0.036]) mm vs 0.045 [(95% CI 0.030 to 0.059]) mm; p=0.028). At five5 years of follow-up, the cIMT values were not different between the groups (0.626 ([0.131]) mm vs 0.602 ([0.108]) mm; p=0.15) (Figure 2Dfigure 2D). Using a linear mixed model, treatment group was associated with a difference in cIMT, independent from the use of biologicals or methotrexate (p<0.001; see for details (online supplementary table S1)).

During five5 years of follow-up, 7seven patients (4.7%) in the usual care group and 5five patients (3.2%) in the treat-to-target group died (p=0.51, log-rank test) (Table 3table 3), with a between-group difference of 1.5% (95% CI −2.9% to –5.9%). Three patients (2.0%) in the usual care group died of cardiovascular cause and none in the treat-to-target group (p=0.07), with a between-group difference of 1.2% (95% CI −0.2% to –4.3%). A total of 11 cardiovascular events occurred during the study, with 99nine first cardiovascular events. There were a A total of 7 (4.7%) first cardiovascular events in the usual care group and 22two events (1.3%) in the treat-to-target group (p=0.048) (Figure 3figure 3), with a between-group difference of 3.4% (95% CI −0.04% to –7.2%).

caption.title: Kaplan-Meier estimates of the composite of first occurrence of fatal and non-fatal cardiovascular events during five5 years of follow-upp. Shown is the cumulative incidence of the composite endpoint of first occurrence of fatal and nonfatal cardiovascular events, including death by cardiovascular cause, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, coronary artery bypass grafting, percutaneous coronary intervention, revascularisation of peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease, or amputation related to peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease. sShown is the cumulative incidence of the composite endpoint of first occurrence of fatal and non-fatal cardiovascular events, including death by cardiovascular cause, non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, coronary artery bypass grafting, percutaneous coronary intervention, revascularisation of peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease, or amputation related to peripheral atherosclerotic arterial disease.
Cardiovascular events, and cardiovascular and all-cause mortality according to treatment groups after five5 years of follow-up.

td.p: Composite of first occurrence of fatal and non-fatal cardiovascular events

fn.p: pP- values were calculated with the use of the log-rank test.

body.p: At baseline, 10 patients with a CVD risk >10% were identified and followed in the high-risk cohort. The Mmean age was 65.6 (2.9) years, 90.0% waswere male, and the median DAS28 was 2.1 (1.6–2.6) (online(online supplementary table s2) ). Five years of treatment significantly reduced their blood pressure and LDL-C. At baseline, their cIMT was 0.751 (0.085) mm and the five5 -years change of cIMT was −0.056 (0.056) mm (online supplementary figure s2)(online ).
body.title: Discussion
body.p: This study evaluated prospectively an intervention regarding CVD risk factors in patients with well-treated RA with a low CVD risk. We show a significant reduction in the progression of subclinical atherosclerosis in patients with RA patients. Furthermore, a reduction in the first occurrence of cardiovascular events was found, although the number of events was low.

Multifactorial intervention trials in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) have shown benefit regarding CVD reduction,31 and our study confirms this finding in patients with well-treated patients with RA patients. Although the difference in cIMT progression between the groups was relatively small in absolute terms, the relative reduction in progression was almost 50% in favorfavour of the treat-to-target group. In light of the reduction of cardiovascular events, these effects are, in our opinion, clinically relevant. This is also supported by the observed effects in the high-risk patients, who were treated according to the treat-to-target protocol resulting in stabilizationstabilisation of cIMT during follow-up. The mixed model analysis further supported the beneficial effects of the intervention. It should be noted that our study included a relatively small number of participants and a small number of clinical events. Therefore, these data need to be confirmed in larger trials.

The cardiovascular risk in patients with RA has often been compared with the risk of patients with T2DM.1 3 32 Our data suggest that the overall risk for CVD in well-treated RA is not as high as previously thought,1 with a 5 -year risk for first occurrence of cardiovascular events of 4.7% in those randomizedrandomised to usual care. This number is considerably lower compared tocompared with data from cohort studies, in which the 5 -years risk for first events ranges 7%–13%,1 33 or in patients with T2DM in whom the risk ranges 12%–15%.34 35 However, the risk in our cohort seems to be elevated compared tocompared with the general population, in which the prevalence of first CVD event ranges 2.3%–3.2%.36 37 The current CVD risk models either do not take the increased CVD risk into account in subjects with RA subjects (eg,for example the Framingham38 and SCORE25 tables) or overestimate the risk (eg,for example the Dutch CVD risk management guidelines.19). Therefore, the current European League Against RheumatismEULAR guidelines,,20 where the calculated risk is multiplied by a factor of 1.5, seems to be the best clinical option so far.

Atherosclerosis has a multifactorial genesis, with many factors involved including inflammation.6 The chronic inflammation in RA has been associated with the development of atherosclerosis,7 and therefore control of disease activity remains the primary goal. Advances in the treatment of RA might explain the reduced CVD risk found in our study. Effective treatment of disease activity leading to less systemic inflammation with methotrexate and biologicals, is considered to be partly responsible for the reduction of CVD events.13 39 The CARdiovascular research and RhEumatoid arthritis (CARRÉ)- study found a CVD event rate of 12.9%;, however, only 10% of patients with RA were treated with a biological compared tocompared with 40% in our study. The median DAS28 in our trial was lower compared tocompared with the CARRÉ- study (2.4 vs 3.8), which could explain, in part, the low incidence of subclinical and clinical atherosclerosis observed here.

Only patients with RA patients without clinical CVD and with an estimated 10 -years risk for fatal CVD below 10%, according to the 2006 SCORE guidelines, were randomizedrandomised. Therefore, the CVD risk found in our study may underestimate the CVD risk in a general RA cohort. Furthermore, even though the majority of our patients had a low disease activity, only a quarter of our patients reached Boolean-based RA remission.

It should be emphasizedemphasised that our study has several limitations. FirstlyFirst, the drop-out in our study was considerable. Despite this drop-out, we were able to construct a large database using multiple imputation. Differences at baseline and at time of drop-out, between completers and non-completers, were comparable. Furthermore, we were also able to collect reliable information on clinical events. SecondlySecond, cIMT is only a soft endpoint for modern cardiovascular trials. At the start of this study, this was not unusual and many cardiovascular intervention trials used cIMT changes at that time as their primary endpoint. Thirdly, the measurement of the cIMT was not performed blinded, but it was carried out according to a strict protocol with fixed settings. Fourthly, according to current standards, the assessment of clinical endpoints should have been performed by an independent endpoint committee. Finally, a stricter target for LDL-C should have been chosen, which may have resulted in even larger effects.

Of note, due to the study design, usual care patients visited our outpatient clinic for evaluation. Their primary care physicians received information and recommendations on cardiovascular risk management resembling the intervention applied to our treat-to-target group. This probably led to a more intensive treatment of usual care patients, and it may explain for example the fact that blood pressure was so well controlled in both groups. In our opinion, this may lead to an underestimation of the absolute risk found in these patients.

Our study shows a larger cIMT progression than estimated by our sample size calculation. Due to limited data on cIMT progression in patients with RA patients, data from other cohorts waswere used to perform the power calculation. For the effect of the intervention, we used data from a multifactorial intervention in T2DM which showed an almost 50% reduction in CVD events. We had doubts whether this high risk would apply to patients with RA patients and therefore used a more conservative target of 20% reduction for cIMT progression. In addition, we did not expect that this small number of subjects would result in a significantly lower number of events in such a relatively short follow-up period.
In conclusion, the present study provides support for a treat-to-target approach of traditional cardiovascular risk factors in subjects with well-controlled RA subjects.1

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We are grateful to Rene Bakker, Department of Clinical Chemistry, Franciscus Gasthuis & Vlietland, for the development of the study database and technical support in data management, as well as Jessica van de Arend, Mathilde Kool, Sonja Belchior and Chantal Geel, specialised rheumatology nurses from the Department of Rheumatology, and Evelien Kars, specialised vascular nurse, Diabetes and Vascular Center, Franciscus Gasthuis & Vlietland, Rotterdam, for their excellent role in taking care of the patients.

email-content.mail-subject: Proof of your article for Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases - 10.1136/annrheumdis-2018-214075

mail-body.p: I’m pleased to provide the proof of your article, which is available on our author proofing system here:

Please submit any corrections then ensure you click ‘Approve’ to complete the author proofing process. Signing off the paper will send the article back to the Production team so they can make any changes.
Please note, the online author proofing system cannot be used in the browser Internet Explorer. Please review your proofs in Google Chrome.

A PDF version of the proof is available to download and review, but all corrections must be submitted using the online system. Please contact us at production.ard@bmj.com if you need any help using this.

This is the only opportunity you will have to correct your article before publication, so please review it carefully. Please ensure you respond to queries listed in the article. Minor errors cannot be corrected after publication and any serious scientific errors will result in a formal correction.
Reprints: If you wish to purchase reprints of your article, please fill in the reprint form.
Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases Production Team
